title: Controversy Surrounds Harshvardhan Kapoor, As He Talks About Losing Out On A Filmfare Award
text:
None of those things just entitled to my opinion like the rest of the world is https://t.co/OkYwxJsMeF — Harshvardhan Kapoor (@HarshKapoor_) January 18, 2017 so we shall all behave like robots from now on , and not share our thoughts and feelings , u ask for honesty then complain when we are https://t.co/DcZt61giho — Harshvardhan Kapoor (@HarshKapoor_) January 18, 2017 @HarshKapoor_ especially Diljit, who really broke boundaries for Punjabi actors and delivered a knockout performance in Udta Punjab. — A Filmi Fanatic (@Chokra_Jawaan) January 19, 2017 The guy was in a Hindi film in 2008 https://t.co/moQh4BxEbZ — Harshvardhan Kapoor (@HarshKapoor_) January 19, 2017 
Even the executive editor of Filmfare , Anuradha Choudhary, low-key tweeted about the actor, calling him out on his self-entitlement, though she didn't take any names. The sense of self entitlement some of these newcomer actors have is beyond imagination. If only they were half as talented. 
To which Harshvardhan responded with a series of tweets, saying: Just take my name https://t.co/D2Y3ivBbQW — Harshvardhan Kapoor (@HarshKapoor_) January 19, 2017 And go through people's filmographys while your at it https://t.co/D2Y3ivBbQW — Harshvardhan Kapoor (@HarshKapoor_) January 19, 2017 It's amazing , you can't share your thoughts at all , then you become the anatagonist you guys run a business on things actors say https://t.co/D2Y3ivBbQW — Harshvardhan Kapoor (@HarshKapoor_) January 19, 2017 It's not entitlement it's an opinion just like how your magazine always has one https://t.co/D2Y3ivBbQW — Harshvardhan Kapoor (@HarshKapoor_) January 19, 2017 Don't feel entitled to any award,I'm questioning the principle of who is a newcomer,have zero problems losing to a genuine newcomer — Harshvardhan Kapoor (@HarshKapoor_) January 19, 2017 
Here's our take on the whole situation. We agree, that everyone has a right to their opinion. But not every opinion needs to be broadcast multiple times across various platforms, till you sound like a petulant child. We get that Harshvardhan is disappointed about not winning the award, but there's no need to drag someone else down because of your warped view of a technicality. Yes, Diljit has acted in Punjabi films, and made an appearance in a Hindi one, but he still comes from a completely different industry. This was his first ever full-fledged role in a Hindi film, and we, and Filmfare , think this counts as a debut. Plus, you've won the other awards in the same category. Missing out on one shouldn't be such a big deal. And, in what we can see as a long career ahead of Harshvardhan, we're sure he'll have countless more opportunities to win prizes. We hope Harshvardhan learns to look forward to the future, instead of making a big deal out of the past. Image credit: Getty Images
